{{Infobox scientist | name = Jeffrey Skolnick | website = {{URL|http://www.biology.gatech.edu/people/jeffrey-skolnick}} | fields = {{ublist |[[Systems biology]] |[[Computational biology]] |[[Bioinformatics]] |[[Cancer]] [[metabolomics]] |[[Protein structure]] prediction |[[Molecular evolution|Protein evolution]] |[[Drug design]] |[[Virtual Cell|Simulation of virtual cells]]}} | workplaces = {{ublist |[[Georgia Tech Research Institute]] |[[Intellimedix]]}} | thesis_title = Investigations on a Rod Like Polyelectrolyte Model | thesis_year = 1978 | doctoral_advisor = Professor Marshall Fixman; Ph.D. | thesis_url = <!--(or | thesis1_url = and | thesis2_url = )--> | native_name = | native_name_lang = <!-- Commented out because image was deleted: | image = Jeffrey-Skolnick.jpg --> | imagesize = 100 | alt = | caption = | birth_date = <!--{{birth date |YYYY|MM|DD}}--> | birth_place = [[Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | death_date = <!--{{death date and age |YYYY|MM|DD |YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date)--> | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!--{{coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline,title}}--> | other_names = | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = | patrons = | alma_mater = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = computational techniques for protein structure analysis | influences = | influenced = | awards = {{ublist |1983 Alfred P. Sloan Research Fellowship |2001 [[American Association for the Advancement of Science]] Fellow |2004 [[Biophysical Society]] Fellow |2003 Stockton Kimball Award |University at Buffalo, Medical Alumni Award |[[Academy of Science, St. Louis|St. Louis Academy of Science]] Fellow |Southeastern University Research Alliance 2014 Distinguished Scientist Award }} | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | spouse = <!--(or | spouses = )--> | partner = <!--(or | partners = )--> | children = | signature = <!--(filename only)--> | signature_alt = | footnotes = }} '''Jeffrey Skolnick''' is an American [[Computational biology|computational biologist]]. He is currently a [[Georgia Institute of Technology]] School of Biology Professor, the Director of the [[Center for the Study of Systems Biology]], the Mary and Maisie Gibson Chair, the [[Georgia Research Alliance]] Eminent Scholar in Computational Systems Biology, the Director of the [[Integrative BioSystems Institute]], and Scientific Advisor at Intellimedix.<ref name=SURA>{{cite news|title=SURA Honors Georgia Tech Biologist as Distinguished Scientist|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-362981673.html|accessdate=3 August 2014|work=Proteomics Weekly|publisher=NewsRX|date=March 24, 2014}}</ref>
He has focused on the development of computational algorithms and their application to proteomes for the prediction of protein structure and function, the prediction of small molecule ligand-protein interactions with applications to drug discovery, the prediction of off-target uses of existing drugs, and the exploration of the interplay between protein physics and evolution in determining protein structure and function.
Skolnick is most known for demonstrating that the number of [[Ligand (biochemistry)#Receptor/ligand binding affinity|ligand]] [[Protein#Cell signaling and ligand binding|binding pockets]] in proteins is quite small, thereby justifying the likelihood that large scale drug repurposing will work. This combined with the ability to use predicted as well as experimental structures in virtual ligand screening at higher accuracy and precision than existing approaches will enable FDA approved drugs with novel mechanisms of action to be identified computationally with a high likelihood of experimental success.<ref name=completeness1>{{cite journal|last1=Zhang|first1=Y.|last2=Hubner|first2=I. A.|last3=Arakaki|first3=A. K.|last4=Shakhnovich|first4=E.|last5=Skolnick|first5=J.|title=On the origin and highly likely completeness of single-domain protein structures|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|date=14 February 2006|volume=103|issue=8|pages=2605–2610|doi=10.1073/pnas.0509379103|pmid=16478803|pmc=1413790}}</ref><ref name=completeness2>{{cite journal|last1=Skolnick|first1=Jeffrey|last2=Zhou|first2=Hongyi|last3=Brylinski|first3=Michal|title=Further Evidence for the Likely Completeness of the Library of Solved Single Domain Protein Structures|journal=The Journal of Physical Chemistry B|date=14 June 2012|volume=116|issue=23|pages=6654–6664|doi=10.1021/jp211052j|pmc=3351587|pmid=22272723}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Protein study suggests drug side effects are inevitable|journal=Drug Discovery Today|date=May 23, 2013|url=http://www.drugdiscoverytoday.com/view/32521/protein-study-suggests-drug-side-effects-are-inevitable/}}</ref>
== Major Discoveries ==
=== Completeness of the library of protein structures and interactions ===
Skolnick was first to demonstrate that the library of single domain protein structures is likely complete and that the observed folds in nature arise from the confinement of dense polymer chains. He further demonstrated that the confinement of these dense polymer chains plus hydrodynamic interactions were the dominant contributor to diffusive processes in cells. Moreover, that the hydrodynamic interactions introduced large scale temporal and spatial correlations that may have important functional consequences.<ref name=completeness1 /><ref name=completeness2 /><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Zhang|first1=Yang|title=Protein structure prediction: when is it useful?|journal=Current Opinion in Structural Biology|volume=19|issue=2|pages=145–155|doi=10.1016/j.sbi.2009.02.005|pmc=2673339}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Saltsman|first1=Kirstie|title=Modeling How Molecules Move Inside Cells|url=http://publications.nigms.nih.gov/computinglife/molecules_move.htm|publisher=National Institutes of Health}}</ref>
=== Ligand homology modeling === He also pioneered the field of ligand homology modeling with his threading based, FINDSITE approach for protein function inference, binding site prediction and virtual ligand screening. The research showed that remotely related proteins identified by threading often share a common ligand binding site occupied by chemically similar ligands that contain strongly conserved anchor functional groups as well as a variable region that accounts for their binding specificity. These insights enable low-resolution predicted structures to be used for ligand screening/binding pose prediction, with comparable accuracy as with high-resolution experimental structures. In virtual ligand screening, the latest version, FINDSITEcomb, was shown to work far better than more traditional virtual screening approaches on both predicted and high resolution experimental structures.<ref name=findsite>{{cite journal|last1=Brylinski|first1=M.|last2=Skolnick|first2=J.|title=A threading-based method (FINDSITE) for ligand-binding site prediction and functional annotation|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|date=28 December 2007|volume=105|issue=1|pages=129–134|doi=10.1073/pnas.0707684105|pmid=18165317|pmc=2224172}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Karypis|first1=George|last2=Rangwala|first2=Huzefa|title=Introduction to Protein Structure Prediction: Methods and Algorithms|date=March 16, 2011|publisher=John Wiley & Sons,|isbn=1-118-09946-X|page=349}}</ref>
=== TASSER protein structure prediction === He also developed the TASSER protein structure prediction approach, whose variants are the top performers in [[CASP]] and the basis for the [[I-TASSER]] service. TASSER was among the first methods whose models are closer to the native structure than the starting template.<ref name=tasser>{{cite journal|last1=Zhang|first1=Yang|last2=Arakaki|first2=Adrian K.|last3=Skolnick|first3=Jeffrey|title=TASSER: An automated method for the prediction of protein tertiary structures in CASP6|journal=Proteins: Structure, Function, and Bioinformatics|volume=61|issue=S7|pages=91–98|doi=10.1002/prot.20724}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Roy|first1=Ambrish|last2=Kucukural|first2=Alper|last3=Zhang|first3=Yang|title=I-TASSER: a unified platform for automated protein structure and function prediction|journal=Nature Protocols|date=25 March 2010|volume=5|issue=4|pages=725–738|doi=10.1038/nprot.2010.5|pmid=20360767|pmc=2849174}}</ref>
=== Odijk-Skolnick-Fixman electrostatic persistence length === Skolnick's Ph.D. thesis " “Investigations on a Rod Like Polyelectrolyte Model", along with Fixman and Odijk, developed a theory for the electrostatic persistence length in polyelectrolytes now known as the [[Odijk-Skolnick-Fixman electrostatic persistence length]] which is still considered the classical benchmark.<ref name=thesis>{{cite journal|last1=Skolnick|first1=Jeffrey|last2=Fixman|first2=Marshall|title=Electrostatic Persistence Length of a Wormlike Polyelectrolyte|journal=Macromolecules|volume=10|issue=5|pages=944–948|doi=10.1021/ma60059a011}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Dias|first1=Rita|last2=Lindman|first2=Bjorn|title=DNA Interactions with Polymers and Surfactants|publisher=John Wiley & Sons,|page=26}}</ref>
== Education == Skolnick graduated Summa Cum Laude from Washington University in 1975 with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Chemistry. After Washington University, he moved on to Yale where he graduated with a Master of Philosophy in Chemistry in 1977 and a Ph.D. in Chemistry just one year later in 1978.
His Ph.D. thesis, “Investigations on a Rod Like Polyelectrolyte Model”, focused on polymer statistical mechanics with Dr. Marshall Fixman. The methods described by Skolnick and Fixman and independently developed by Theo Odijk are still used as the basis for the electrostatic persistence length of polyelectrolytes.<ref name=thesis />
== Academic Recognition ==
=== Awards === Skolnick has been recognized as a Fellow with the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the Biophysical Society, and the St. Louis Academy of Science. He has also been awarded an Alfred P. Sloan Research Fellowship.<ref>{{cite web|title=Past Fellows|url=http://www.sloan.org/fellowships/past-fellows/|publisher=Alfred P. Sloan Foundation|accessdate=3 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=AAAS News & Notes |url=http://www.aaas.org/news |publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science |archivedate=30 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120730193922/http://www.aaas.org/news/newsandnotes/inside77.shtml |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Fellow of the Biophysical Society Award|url=http://www.biophysics.org/AwardsFunding/SocietyAwards/FellowoftheBiophysicalSocietyAward/tabid/501/Default.aspx|website=http://www.biophysics.org|publisher=Biophysical Society|accessdate=3 August 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Academy Fellows|url=http://www.academyofsciencestl.org/initiatives/fellows/s/jeffrey_skolnick.php|website=http://www.academyofsciencestl.org|publisher=St. Louis Academy of Science|accessdate=3 August 2014}}</ref>
=== Journals and Editorial Boards === {| class="wikitable" |- ! Dates !! Journal |- | 2012–present || Editorial Board, PeerJ<ref>{{cite web|title=Advisory Board and Editors Computational Biology|url=https://peerj.com/academic-boards/subjects/13/Computational-Biology/?page=6|website=http://peerj.com/|publisher=PeerJ|accessdate=3 August 2014}}</ref> |- | 2012–present || Structural Biology Section Editor, Biology Direct<ref name=biologydirect>{{cite web|title=Editorial Board|url=http://www.biologydirect.com/about/edboard|website=http://www.biologydirect.com|publisher=Biology Direct|accessdate=3 August 2014}}</ref> |- | 2011–present || Editorial Board, Current Bioinformatics<ref>{{cite web|title=Editorial Board ::: Current Bioinformatics|url=http://benthamscience.com/journal/editorial-board.php?journalID=cbio#top|publisher=Bentham Science|accessdate=3 August 2014}}</ref> |- | 2005–present || Editorial Board, Biology Direct<ref name=biologydirect /> |- | 2005–present || Editorial Board, Protein Science<ref>{{cite web|title=Protein Science - Editorial Board - Wiley Online Library|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/(ISSN)1469-896X/homepage/EditorialBoard.html|website=http://wiley.com/|publisher=Wiley|accessdate=3 August 2014}}</ref> |- | 1998–present || Editorial Board, Proteins<ref>{{cite web|title=Proteins: Structure, Function, and Bioinformatics - Editorial Board - Wiley Online Library|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/(ISSN)1097-0134/homepage/EditorialBoard.html|website=http://wiley.com|publisher=Wiley|accessdate=3 August 2014}}</ref> |}
He is also a cofounder of an early stage structural proteomics company, GeneFormatics, and his software has been commercialized by Tripos.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Hoerr|first1=Dorothy|title=The Business of Biotech|url=http://www.albright.edu/reporter/fall2002/biotech.html|publisher=Albright College|accessdate=3 August 2014}}</ref>
== Professional career == {| class="wikitable" |- ! Dates !! Position |- | 2010–present || Director, Integrated Biosystems Institute, Georgia Institute of Technology<ref name=SURA /> |- | 2008–present || Mary and Maisie Gibson Chair in Computational Systems Biology<ref>{{cite web|title=DRUG DISCOVERY & THERAPY WORLD CONGRESS 2015|url=http://www.ddtwc.com/ProminentParticipants.php|website=http://www.ddtwc.com/|accessdate=3 August 2014}}</ref> |- | 2008–2010 || Associate Director, Integrated Biosystems Institute, Georgia Institute of Technology<ref name=SURA /> |- | 2007–2012 || Adjunct Professor, School of Chemistry & Biochemistry, Georgia Institute of Technology |- | 2006–present || Director, Center for the Study of Systems Biology, Georgia Institute of Technology<ref name=SURA /> |- | 2006–present || GRA Eminent Scholar, Computational Systems Biology <ref name=SURA /> |- | 2006–present || Professor, School of Biology, Georgia Institute of Technology<ref>{{cite news|title=Georgia Tech Research Suggests Drug Side Effects Are Inevitable|url=http://globalbiodefense.com/2013/05/23/georgia-tech-research-suggests-drug-side-effects-are-inevitable/|accessdate=3 August 2014|work=Global Biodefense|publisher=Stemar Media Group, LLC.}}</ref> |- | 2002–2005 || Director, Buffalo Center of Excellence in Bioinformatics<ref>{{cite news|last1=Drury|first1=Tracey|title=Bioinformatics scientists stoked by UB's Simpson|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/buffalo/stories/2004/03/01/story3.html|accessdate=3 August 2014|work=Buffalo Business First|publisher=The Business Journals|date=1 March 2004}}</ref> |- | 2002–2005 || Professor, Structural Biology, University at Buffalo<ref>{{cite news|title=UB Honors Pataki, Welcomes New Bioinformatics Director|url=http://news.wbfo.org/post/ub-honors-pataki-welcomes-new-bioinformatics-director|accessdate=3 August 2014|work=WBFO Buffalo's NPR News Station|date=10 May 2002}}</ref> |- | 1999–2002 || Director, Computational/Structural Biology, Danforth Plant Science Center<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hopkin|first1=Karen|title=Computational Biologists Join the Fold|url=http://www.bio-itworld.com/archive/061202/fold.html|accessdate=3 August 2014|work=Bio-ITWorld|publisher=Cambridge Healthtech Institute|date=12 June 2002}}</ref> |}
== Patents ==
Patent No. 5,265,030 issued 11/23/1993. System and method for determining three-dimensional structures of proteins. Jeffrey Skolnick and Andrzej Kolinski Inventors.<ref>{{cite patent |country=US |number=5265030 |status=patent}}</ref>
Patent No. 5,933,819 issued 8/3/1999. Prediction of relative binding motifs of biologically active peptides and peptide mimetics. Jeffrey Skolnick, Mariusz Milik and Andrzej Kolinski Inventors.<ref>{{cite patent |country=US |number=5933819 |status=patent}}</ref>
Patent No. 6,631,332, issued 10/7/2003. Methods for using functional site descriptors and predicting protein function. Jeffrey Skolnick and [[Jacquelyn S. Fetrow]] Inventors.<ref>{{cite patent |country=US |number=6631332 |status=patent}}</ref>
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using tags, these references will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://cssb.biology.gatech.edu/skolnick/people/jeff.html Jeffrey Skolnick – Center for the Study of Systems Biology] * [http://intellimedix.com/about/our-team-2/ Our Team - Intellimedix]

{{ad|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox organization | name = LEAP Science and Maths Schools | logo = | type = [[Nonprofit organization]] | founded_date = 1987 | founder = John Gilmour | location = [[South Africa]] | origins = | key_people = John Gilmour – ''Founder and Executive director''
Grant Nupen – ''Board Chairman''
Grant Clark – ''Member of the Board''
Leon Glanvill – ''Member of the Board''
Joe Kainja – ''Member of the Board''
Mackie Kleinschmidt – ''Member of the Board''
Heidi Raubenheimer – ''Member of the Board''
Ben Rabinowitz – ''Member of the Board''
Crispin Sonn – ''Member of the Board''
Jasper Walsh – ''Member of the Board'' | area_served = | focus = Eliminate Educational Inequity | method = | revenue = | endowment = | acceptance rate 2013 = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = Educating Future Leaders | homepage = http://leapschool.org.za/ | tax_exempt = | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''Langa Education Assistance Program (LEAP)''', also known as '''LEAP Science and Maths Schools''', is a collection of six non-fee payment secondary education schools located in three provinces in [[South Africa]]. The first LEAP school opened in 2004 in rented premises in Observatory, [[Cape Town]] and served mainly, learners from the [[township]] of [[Langa, Cape Town|Langa]].{{Cite web|url = http://leapschool.org.za/history-of-leap/|archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20141110010101/http://leapschool.org.za/history%2Dof%2Dleap/|title = History of LEAP|accessdate = 10 November 2014|archivedate=10 November 2014|dead-url = yes|publisher=LEAP Science and Maths Schools}} As an independent school, LEAP is mainly founded by South African Corporates with limited subsidies from the [[South African Department of Education|Department of Basic Education]]. ==History== ===Langa Education Assistance Program (or LEAP) === John Gilmour was a teacher at [[Pinelands High School]] in Cape Town in 1987 when he decided to respond to a call from individuals within the South African business community, to contribute to the redress of the devastation of the [[Bantu Education Act]], a segregation law imposed in the education sector by the [[Apartheid]] system in 1953. “Africa Week” was then introduced by a team led by John Gilmour to bring black learners under the “Bantu Education” system to spend a week at Pinelands High School, which was then a white’s only school. The program became the precursor for the Langa Education Assistance Program (or LEAP) which aimed at providing one hundred black students from the Langa township, with support tuition from Pinelands High teachers in [[English language|English]], [[Maths]] and [[Science]], three afternoons a week. The prohibitive transport cost of bringing learners from the township schools to Pinelands High School forced the model to be revised. In 1996, it was then decided that instead of learners being bussed in to Pinelands High, teachers will be transported to meet learners in township schools. Community members in Langa perceived the new model of LEAP as an attempt of white teachers to “save” black children. Teachers from the community felt that they were as able as other teachers to provide extra lessons that would address the inadequacies in the students' educational foundations. The uneasiness within the community obliged the leadership of LEAP to change the model and include community teachers in the program. When John Gilmour realised that despite best efforts of LEAP and similar programs in the country there was no increase in the proportion of black learners entering university, especially science-based disciplines, he sought for an alternative model. LEAP Science and Maths school was the alternative model. ===LEAP Science and Maths School=== LEAP Science and Maths school was a deliberate decision of John Gilmour seeking to increase the number of black learners who take science and maths-based modules at high school in order to increase the chance of being accepted at University, particular in disciplines where these modules are a prerequisite.{{cite news|last1=Terblanche|first1=Barry|title=A leap in the dark|publisher=Mail and Guardian|date=19 August 2009}} John resigned as Headmaster of Abbot’s College in 2004, where he has been since he left Pinelands in 1997, to focus on LEAP Science and Maths School. In January 2004, the first LEAP Science and Maths School opened its doors in the suburb of Observatory, Cape Town, with seventy-two learners, seven teachers and one administrative staff member. ===Expansion of the LEAP model=== ====LEAP 1==== The LEAP Science and Maths school, which started in Observatory later moved to Pinelands and become known as LEAP 1. It serves learners from community of Langa Township. It is the first and oldest of the LEAP Science and Maths schools. The school is headed by its Operation Leader Oscar Dlodlo. ====LEAP 2==== LEAP 2 opened in 2007 also in Pinelands. It serves learners from the townships of Gugulethu and Crossroads. In 2013, the school opened satellite classes to serve grade 9 and 10 learners from the township of Delft. Learners of the school are taught in English and [[isiXhosa]]. The head of the school is Mr. Babele Emedi, who also assumes the role of Operations Leader. ====LEAP 3==== The school opened its doors in 2008 to serve learners from the township of Alexandra in [[Johannesburg]]. Learners are taught in [[English language|English]], [[isiZulu]], [[Sepedi]] and [[Sesotho]] under the leadership of the Operations leader, Mr. Mark Fletcher. ====LEAP 4==== This school is situated in the township of [[Diepsloot]] just outside Johannesburg. The school opened in 2011 through a partnership with the South Africa corporate Aveng Group.{{cite web|title=Aveng Group Projects|url=http://www.aveng.co.za/csi-trust/projects/leap-science-and-maths-school|website=http://www.aveng.co.za/csi-trust/projects/leap-science-and-maths-school|publisher=Aveng Group|accessdate=10 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141003105051/http://www.aveng.co.za/csi-trust/projects/leap-science-and-maths-school|archivedate=3 October 2014|df=}} LEAP 4 teaches learners in isiZulu and [[Sepedi]] as home languages, along with English. Paul Mumba, is the Operations Leader and head of LEAP 4. ====LEAP 5==== In 2012, LEAP 5 opened its doors in Jane Furse, [[Sekhukhune District Municipality|Sekhukhune]] in [[Limpopo]] province. The school is under the leadership of its Operation Leader, Raphael Mukachi. ====LEAP 6==== LEAP 6 is situated in [[Ga-Rankuwa]] near [[Pretoria]]. The school opened in 2012 to respond to the request of the Anglican Diocese of Pretoria, concerned with the community’s poor educational results and high unemployment rate, particularly among young people. The school is led by its Operation Leader, Lawrence Manyesa. ==Vision== “We strive for the positive transformation of communities through the meaningful education of children from those communities”{{cite web|title=About LEAP|url=http://leapschool.org.za/aboutleap/|website=http://leapschool.org.za/aboutleap/|publisher=LEAP Science and Maths Schools|accessdate=10 November 2014}} ==Mission== “LEAP schools provide student-centered, math’s and science-focused education to economically disadvantaged students from grades 8 to 12. We focus on enabling the self-awareness necessary for each student’s growth to healthy adulthood, and to ensuring optimal academic results which will allow for choices for lifelong learning and a fulfilling future.” == Values and focus== Although LEAP schools focus on Maths and Sciences; it puts a lot of emphasis on the emotional [[child development|development]] of learners.{{cite news|last1=Dugger|first1=Celia W|title=New Schools in South Africa Serve the Underserved|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/09/world/africa/09safrica.html?pagewanted=all&_r=3&|accessdate=10 November 2014|publisher=New York Times|date=8 September 2010|ref=New Schools in South Africa Serve the Underserved}} John Gilmour acknowledged the importance of the emotional development in a country where “eight million children come from single-parent households and a further 4.3 million reside with neither biological parent”. In his article “A tale of two systems”, he speaks of LEAP’s response to this problem “has been to recognise that social transformation starts with personal transformation: one person at a time, one room at a time, one school at a time and one community at a time.”{{cite web|last1=Gilmour|first1=John|title=A tale of two systems|url=http://leapschool.org.za/2012/02/12/a-tail-of-two-systems/|website=http://leapschool.org.za/|publisher=LEAP Science and Maths Schools|accessdate=10 November 2014}} The school cherishes the following values: *Being kind, honest and healthy *Being punctual and looking good *Working hard and never giving up *Admitting and learning from mistakes *Confronting issues and being open to change *Working together and sharing == Success stories== ===Statistics=== In a report that analyses the performance of the school between 2005 and 2013, LEAP reported that: *Its grade 12 learners have achieved a 93% pass rate within the reporting period. *600 learners passed the National Senior Certificate (NSC) examinations commonly known as “matric” *77% qualified for study at academic and technical universities with a bachelor or diploma pass.{{cite web|title=Success|url=http://leapschool.org.za/success/|website=http://leapschool.org.za/success/|publisher=LEAP Science and Maths Schools|accessdate=10 November 2014}} The school claims to outperform national statistics when it compares itself with national averages of learners who write maths and science in 2013. All LEAP learners wrote these modules compared to only 43% who took maths and 33% who took physical science nationally.{{cite web|title=LEAP Annual Report 2013|url=http://leapschool.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/LEAP_AnnualReport2013.pdf|website=http://leapschool.org.za/wp-content/uploads/2014/06/LEAP_AnnualReport2013.pdf|publisher=LEAP Science and Maths Schools|accessdate=10 November 2014}} ===Graduates=== Bonisanani Mtshekisa{{cite web|last1=Mtshekisa|first1=Bonisanani|title=Never Give Up|url=http://leapschool.org.za/2011/08/08/never-give-up/|website=http://leapschool.org.za/2011/08/08/never-give-up/|publisher=LEAP Science and Maths Schools|accessdate=10 November 2014}} is LEAP’s first university graduate. He graduated with a bachelor in [[Bachelor of Commerce]] in Finance from the [[University of the Western Cape]]. In its 2012 annual report, the school reported to have over 30 university graduates ranging from physiotherapist, engineer to accountants. ===Celebratory adverts=== In 2014, LEAP launched a series of celebratory adverts to showcase its work and celebrate the achievements of its past students. Qondisa Nxganga, a Master’s graduate from the prestigious [[African Institute for Mathematical Sciences]] (AIMS), is featured in these adverts alongside a number of other LEAP alumni.{{cite web|title=Celebrating LEAP Alumni|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jPYGiXxlQCo|website=www.youtube.com|publisher=LEAP Science & Maths School|accessdate=10 November 2014}} ===Partnerships=== LEAP’s model is based on strong engagement with the broader community and building beneficial partnerships and collaboration with other organizations, particular schools. It is a three-way collaboration approach where each LEAP school partners with a more privileged school as well as a less privileged school (a township school) in the community where it operates to promote a culture of shared resources and cultural exchange{{cite web|title=Schools|url=http://leapschool.org.za/schools/|website=http://leapschool.org.za/schools/|publisher=LEAP Science and Maths Schools|accessdate=10 November 2014}} LEAP has also been successful in building strong partnerships with both commercial and non-profit organizations. Most of its funding comes from South African corporates, trusts and Foundations. LEAP, is Teach with Africa’s partner on the continent and together they have established the Teacher Institute which seeks to develop teachers and supports individuals wanting to enter the teaching profession{{cite web|title=Teach for Africa|url=http://www.teachwithafrica.org/what-we-do/our-in-country-partners/|website=http://www.teachwithafrica.org/what-we-do/our-in-country-partners/|accessdate=10 November 2014}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Facebook|leapschool}} *http://www.educationinnovations.org/program/leap-science-and-maths-schools *http://dogreatthings.co.za/foundation/education/leap-science-and-maths-school/ *http://www.givengain.com/cause/3841/ [[Category:1987 establishments in South Africa]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1987]] [[Category:Educational organisations in South Africa]] [[Category:Schools of mathematics]] [[Category:Science education]]

{{Unreferenced|date=November 2018}} The '''magnetosheath''' is the region of space between the [[magnetopause]] and the [[bow shock]] of a [[planet|planet's]] [[magnetosphere]]. The regularly organized [[magnetic field]] generated by the planet becomes weak and irregular in the magnetosheath due to interaction with the incoming [[solar wind]], and is incapable of fully deflecting the highly [[charged particle]]s. The density of the particles in this region is considerably lower than what is found beyond the bow shock, but greater than within the [[magnetopause]], and can be considered a transitory state.
[[Image:Structure_of_the_magnetosphere-en.svg|thumb|350px|Schematic of Earth's magnetosphere, showing the relative position of the magnetosheath]]
Scientific research into the exact nature of the magnetosheath has been limited due to a longstanding misconception that it was a simple byproduct of the bow shock/magnetopause interaction and had no inherently important properties of its own. Recent studies indicate, however, that the magnetosheath is a dynamic region of turbulent [[Plasma (physics)|plasma]] flow that may play an important role in the structure of the bow shock and the magnetopause, and may help to dictate the flow of energetic particles across those boundaries.{{Citation needed|date=July 2007}}
The [[Earth]]'s magnetosheath typically occupies the region of space approximately 10 Earth radii on the upwind ([[Sun]]-facing) side of the planet, extending significantly farther out on the downwind side due to the pressure of the solar wind. The exact location and width of the magnetosheath does depend on variables such as [[Solar variation|solar activity]].
==See also== * [[Earth's magnetic field]] * [[Interplanetary magnetic field]] (IMF) * [[Magnetotail]] * [[Van Allen radiation belt]] * [[Plasmasphere]] * [[Ionosphere]] * [[Space weather]] and [[heliophysics]]
==External links== * [http://www.daviddarling.info/encyclopedia/M/magnetosheath.html The Encyclopedia of Astrobiology, Astronomy, and Spaceflight] * [http://www-ssc.igpp.ucla.edu/ssc/textbook/magneto.html Institute of Geophysics and Planetary Physics] {{magnetosphere}}
[[Category:Planetary science]] [[Category:Space plasmas]] [[Category:Plasma physics]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Use Indian English|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox University |name = Maharashtra Animal and Fishery Sciences University
Nagpur |native_name = '''महाराष्ट्र पशु व मत्स्य विज्ञान विद्यापीठ, नागपूर ''' |type = [[Education]] and [[Research]] [[Institution]] | |established = 2000 |vice_chancellor= Dr.A. M. Paturkar |city = [[Seminary Hills]], [[Nagpur]] |state = [[Maharashtra]] | |country = {{IND}} | |campus = Headquarters: [[Nagpur]]
Veterinary Campuses: [[Mumbai]], [[Akola]], [[Nagpur]], [[Parbhani]], [[Udgir]] and Shirwal
Dairy Campuses: Warud, Pusad
Fishery Campuses: [[Nagpur]] and [[Udgir]] |website= http://www.mafsu.in/ }} MAFSU formally notified on 17 November 2000 was established under the State Act No. 1998 (Mah XVII of 1998) on 3 December 2000. This university is one of the pioneer institutes related to Veterinary Research and Extension in Central India. ==Campuses/Colleges== The university was carved out of the four Agricultural Universities in the State by transferring five Veterinary colleges, one postgraduate Institute and one dairy technology college, a dairy technology institute and a diploma institute. ===Veterinary Colleges=== # [http://www.nvcnagpur.net.in Nagpur Veterinary College, Nagpur] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20110930041435/http://www.mafsu.in/nagpur/nagpur_main.html]) # [[Bombay Veterinary College, Mumbai]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20110930041504/http://www.mafsu.in/bvc/bvccollege/bvc_main_page.html]) # [[College of Veterinary and Animal Sciences, Parbhani]] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20110930041326/http://www.mafsu.in/parbhani1/parbhani_main.html]) # [http://www.vcudg.in College of Veterinary and Animal Sciences, Udgir] ([https://web.archive.org/web/20110930041318/http://www.mafsu.in/udgir/udgri_main.html]) # revision.comment: /* See also */ I removed all irrelevant links. try to keep it as unbiased and neutral as possible
revision.text:
[[File:MRM symbol.svg|thumb|A claimed Men's rights movement symbol.]] {{masculism sidebar}} '''Masculism''' or '''masculinism''' may variously refer to advocacy of the rights or needs of [[Man|men]] and [[boy]]s; and the adherence to or promotion of attributes (opinions, values, attitudes, habits) regarded as typical of men and boys.<ref name="BunninYu2008"/><ref name="Honderich1995">{{cite book|last=Christensen|first=Ferrell|editor=Ted Honderich|title=The Oxford Companion to Philosophy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4ii8AAAAIAAJ|year=1995|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-866132-0}}</ref><ref name=reason>{{cite news|publisher=''[[Reason magazine|Reason]]''|title=Man Troubles: Making Sense of the Men's Movement|author=[[Cathy Young]]|date=July 1994|url=http://reason.com/archives/1994/07/01/man-troubles|quote=Masculism (mas'kye liz*'em), n. 1. the belief that equality between the sexes requires the recognition and redress of prejudice and discrimination against men as well as women. 2. the movement organized around this belief. References Warren Farrell, Jack Kammer, and others activists in the men's movement.}}</ref>
==Definition and scope== The ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'' (OED) defines ''masculism'', or synonymously ''masculinism'', as the "advocacy of the rights of men; adherence to or promotion of opinions, values, etc., regarded as typical of men; (more generally) anti-feminism, machismo."<ref>{{cite web|title=masculism, n|work=Oxford English Dictionary Online|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|edition=3rd |year=2000|accessdate=2015-02-17|quote=masculism, n. †1. The possession of masculine physical traits by a woman. Obs. rare. 2. = masculinism n.}}</ref><ref name="oedMasculinism">{{cite web|title=masculinism, n|work=Oxford English Dictionary Online|publisher=Oxford University Press|edition=3rd |year=2000|accessdate=2015-02-17|quote=masculinism, n. Advocacy of the rights of men; adherence to or promotion of opinions, values, etc., regarded as typical of men; (more generally) anti-feminism, machismo.}}</ref>
However, philosopher Ferrell Christensen differentiates "masculism" from "masculinism", defining the latter as promoting the attributes of manliness.<ref name="Honderich1995"/> Political scientist Georgia Duerst-Lahti also distinguishes the two terms, with masculism expressing the ethos of the early gender-egalitarian [[men's movement]], while masculinism refers to the ideology of [[patriarchy]].<ref>{{citation | last = Duerst-Lahti | first = Georgia | contribution = Gender Ideology: masculinism and femininalism |pages=159–192 |editor1-last=Goertz |editor1-first=Gary |editor2-last=Mazur |editor2-first=Amy G. |title=Politics, gender, and concepts: theory and methodology |year=2008 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=9780521723428}}</ref><ref name="Dupuis-Déri2009">{{cite journal|last1=Dupuis-Déri|first1=Francis|title=Le " masculinisme ": une histoire politique du mot (en Anglais et en Français)| trans-title = “Masculinism”: a political history of the term (in English and French) |journal=Recherches Féministes |volume=22 |issue=2 |pages=97–123 |url =https://doi.org/10.7202/039213ar |date=2009 |doi=10.7202/039213ar | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref>
Christensen differentiates between "progressive masculism" and an "extremist version". The former welcomes many of the societal changes promoted by feminists, while believing that some measures reducing sexism against women have increased it against men.<ref name="Honderich1995"/> Nicholas Davidson, in his book ''The Failure of Feminism'', describes an extremist version of masculism which he termed "virism": "What ails society is 'effeminacy'. The improvement of society requires that the influence of female values be decreased and the influence of male values increased…."<ref name="Honderich1995"/><ref name="Davidson1988">Christensen, Ferrell (2005), "[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=WbkSDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA562 Masculism]", in {{cite book | editor-last = Honderich | editor-first = Ted | title = The Oxford companion to philosophy |pages=562–563 | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford New York | isbn = 9780199264797 }} * ''Citing'': {{cite book | last = Davidson | first = Nicholas | title = The failure of feminism |page=274 | publisher = Prometheus Books | location = Buffalo, New York | year = 1988 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=pf8pAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA274 | isbn = 9780879754082 }}</ref>
[[Gender theory|Gender theories]], which have frequently focused on woman-based or feminist approaches, have come to examine oppression in a masculist society also from the perspectives of men, many of whom are also subjected by that society.<ref name="HoogensenSolheim2006">Hoogensen, Gunhild; Solheim, Bruce Olav (2006), "[https://books.google.com/?id=ZPThCTMVsZQC&pg=PA21 Women in theory and practice]", in {{cite book | editor-last1 = Hoogensen | editor-first1 = Gunhild | editor-last2 = Solheim | editor-first2 = Bruce Olav |title=Women in power: world leaders since 1960|year=2006|page=21|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=9780275981907}}</ref> From a feminist perspective to philosophy, masculinism seeks to value and include only male views, and claim "that anything that cannot be reduced or translated in men's experience should be excluded from the subject-matter of philosophy.<ref name="BunninYu2008"/>
==Topic areas of interest== {{main|Men's rights movement}}
===Education and employment=== Many masculists oppose co-educational schooling, believing that single-sex schools better promote the well-being of boys.<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"> {{cite journal | last1 = Blais | first1 = Melissa | last2 = Dupuis-Déri | first2 = Francis | title = Masculinism and the antifeminist countermovement | journal = [[Social Movement Studies|Social Movement Studies: Journal of Social, Cultural and Political Protest]] | volume = 11 | issue = 1 | pages = 21–39 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1080/14742837.2012.640532 | date = 2012 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/14742837.2012.640532 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Other masculists and [[Equity feminism|equity feminists]] say that boys lag behind girls in educational achievement.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Sommers |first1=Christina | author-link = Christina Hoff Sommers|title=The war against boys|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2000/05/the-war-against-boys/304659/|work= [[The Atlantic]] | date = May 2000 |accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref>
Data from the U.S. in 1994 reported that men suffer 94% of workplace fatalities. Masculist [[Warren Farrell]] has argued that men do a disproportionate share of dirty, physically demanding, and hazardous jobs.<ref name=reason/>
===Violence and suicide=== {{Violence against men}} {{See also|Violence against men}}
Masculists cite higher rates of suicide in men than women.<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/> Masculists express concern about violence against men being depicted as humorous, in the media and elsewhere.<ref name=MYTH>{{cite book | last = Farrell | first = Warren | author-link = Warren Farrell | title = [[The Myth of Male Power|The myth of male power: why men are the disposable sex]] | publisher = [[Berkley Books]] | location = New York | year = 2001 | isbn = 9780425181447 }}</ref>
They also express concern about violence against men being ignored or minimized in comparison to violence against women,<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/><ref>{{cite news | last = Mvulane | first = Zama | title = Do men suffer spousal abuse? | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090221033948/http://www.iol.co.za/index.php?click_id=13&art_id=vn20081125064002133C731559&set_id= | archive-date = February 21, 2009 | url = http://www.iol.co.za:80/index.php?click_id=13&art_id=vn20081125064002133C731559&set_id= | work = [[Cape Times]] | via = [[Independent Online (South Africa)|IOL]] | location = South Africa | page = 12 | date = November 25, 2008 | deadurl = yes | df = }}</ref> some asserting gender symmetry in [[domestic violence]].<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/> Another of their concerns is that traditional assumptions of female innocence or sympathy for women, termed [[benevolent sexism]], may lead to unequal penalties for women and men who commit similar crimes,<ref name="MYTH" /> to lack of sympathy for male victims in [[domestic violence]] cases, and to dismissal of female-on-male [[sexual assault]] and [[sexual harassment]] cases.
===Custody=== {{main|Fathers' rights movement}} According to [[David Benatar]], head of philosophy at the [[University of Cape Town]], "Custody law is perhaps the best-known area of men's rights activism", as it is more likely in most parts of the world for the mother to obtain custody of children in case of divorce. He argues: "When the man is the primary care-giver his chances of winning custody are lower than when the woman is the primary care-giver. Even when the case is not contested by the mother, he's still not as likely to get custody as when the woman's claim is uncontested".<ref>{{cite news | last = de Castella | first = Tom | title = Just who are men's rights activists? | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-17907534 | work = [[BBC News Online#Features|BBC News Magazine]] | date = May 2, 2012 | access-date = May 3, 2012}}</ref>
== South African masculist evangelical movements == In the wake of the abolition of apartheid, South Africa has seen a resurgence of masculist Christian evangelical groups, led by two complementary men's and women's movements, the Mighty Men movement and the Worthy Women movement.<ref name="Nadar_Potgieter">{{cite journal | last1 = Nadar | first1 = Sarojini | last2 = Potgieter | first2 = Cheryl | title = Liberated through submission?: The Worthy Woman's Conference as a case study of for''men''ism | journal = Journal of Feminist Studies in Religion | volume = 26 | issue = 2 | pages = 141–151 | publisher = [[Project MUSE]] | date = Fall 2010 | url = https://muse.jhu.edu/article/394797 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> The Mighty Men movement harkens back to the Victorian idea of Muscular Christianity<ref name=":0">{{cite journal | last = Dube | first = Siphiwe | title = Muscular Christianity in contemporary South Africa: The case of the Mighty Men Conference | journal = HTS [[Theological Studies/Teologiese Studies]] | volume = 71 | issue = 3 | pages = 1–9 | publisher = AOSIS OpenJournals | date = July 2015 | url = https://hts.org.za/index.php/HTS/article/view/2945/html | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> and the movement does not lead discussions about institutionalized racism.<ref name=":1">{{cite journal | last = Dube | first = Siphiwe | title = Race, whiteness and transformation in the Promise Keepers America and the Mighty Men Conference: A comparative analysis | journal = HTS [[Theological Studies/Teologiese Studies]] | volume = 72 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–8 | publisher = AOSIS OpenJournals | date = November 2016 | url = http://www.hts.org.za/index.php/HTS/article/view/3476/html | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> Feminist scholars argue that the movement's lack of attention to women's rights and their historical struggle with racial equality makes it a threat to women and to the stability of the country.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Scholar Miranda Pillay argues that the Mighty Men movement appeal lies in its resistance to gender equality as incompatible with Christian values, and in raising patriarchy to a "hyper-normative status," beyond challenge by other claims to power.<ref>Pillay, Miranda (2015), "[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=yMTSCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA61 Mighty Men, Mighty Families: A pro-family Christian movement to (re)enforce patriarchal control?]", in {{cite book | editor-last1 = Conradie | editor-first1 = Ernst M. | editor-last2=Pillay| editor-first2=Miranda| title = Ecclesial reform and deform movements in the South African context | pages = 61–77 | publisher = African SUN MeDIA | location = Stellenbosch, South Africa | isbn = 9781920689766}}</ref>
The Worthy Women movement is a women's auxiliary to Mighty Men in advocating ''men''ism, a belief in the inherent superiority of men over women.<ref name="Nadar_Potgieter" /> Their leader is Gretha Wiid. She blames South Africa's disorder on the liberation of women, and aims to restore the nation through its families, making women again subservient to their men.<ref>Nortjé-Meyer, Lilly (2015), "[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=yMTSCQAAQBAJ&pg=PA86 A movement seeking to embody support of patriarchal structures and patterns in church and society: Gertha Wiid's Worthy Women movement]", in {{cite book | editor-last1 = Conradie | editor-first1 = Ernst M. | editor-last2=Pillay| editor-first2=Miranda| title = Ecclesial reform and deform movements in the South African context | pages = 86–93 | publisher = African SUN MeDIA | location = Stellenbosch, South Africa | isbn = 9781920689766}}</ref> Her success is attributed to her balancing claims that God created the gender hierarchy, but that women are no less valuable than men,<ref>{{cite journal | last = Nortjé-Meyer | first = Lilly | title = A critical analysis of Gretha Wiid’s sex ideology and her biblical hermeneutics | journal = Verbum et Ecclesia | volume = 32 | issue = 1 | pages = 1–7 | publisher = AOSIS OpenJournals | date = November 2011 | url = http://verbumetecclesia.org.za/index.php/VE/article/view/472/html | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref> and that restoration of traditional gender roles relieves existential anxiety in post-apartheid South Africa.<ref name="Nadar_Potgieter"/>
==Reactions==
===Criticisms and responses=== Some critics believe masculism focuses on [[Chauvinism#Male chauvinism|male superiority]] or male dominance (i.e. [[androcentrism]])<ref>. ''Responses'': * {{cite web|title=masculinist, n|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/masculinist|website=merriam-webster.com|publisher=[[Merriam-Webster]]|accessdate=July 18, 2011}} * {{cite book | last = Brittan | first = Arthur | title = Masculinity and power|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ptFzQgAACAAJ&pg=PA4 | publisher = Basil Blackwell | location = Oxford New York | year = 1989 | isbn = 9780631141679 |page= 4|quote= ''Masculinism is the ideology that justifies and naturalizes male domination. As such it is the ideology of patriarchy. Masculinism takes it for granted that there is a fundamental difference between man and women, it assumes that heterosexuality is normal, it accepts without question the sexual division of labour, and it sanctions the political and dominant role of men in the public and private spheres.''}} * {{cite journal|last=Kahl|first=David H.|title=Analyzing Masculinist Movements: Responding to Antifeminism through Critical Communication Pedagogy|journal=Communication Teacher|volume=29|issue=1|year=2015|pages=21–26|doi=10.1080/17404622.2014.985600}} * Ruth, Sheila (1990), "[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=HzYFAQAAIAAJ&pg=PT7 An introduction to women's studies]", in {{cite book | editor-last = Ruth | editor-first = Sheila | title = Issues in feminism: an introduction to women's studies | page = 7 | publisher = Mayfield | location = Mountain View, California | edition = 2nd | isbn = 9780874849370 | quote = ''Masculine-ism or masculism (sometimes called androcentrism) is the elevation of the masculine, conceptually and physically, to the level of the universal and ideal.'' }}</ref> to the exclusion of [[Woman|women]].<ref name="BunninYu2008">Bunnin, Nicholas; Yu, Jiyuan (2004), "[https://books.google.com/books?id=LdbxabeToQYC&pg=PA411 Masculinism]", in {{cite book | editor-last1 = Bunnin | editor-first1 = Nicholas | editor-last2 = Yu | editor-first2 = Jiyuan | title = The Blackwell dictionary of Western philosophy |page=411 | publisher = Blackwell | location = Malden, Massachusetts | year = 2004 | isbn = 9780470997215 }}</ref> Some masculinists believe that differentiated gender roles are natural. {{non-sequitur|date=July 2018}} There is some evidence for social influences (e.g. gender division of labor, socialization) as the sole or primary origin of gender differentiation.<ref name="Risman, Barbara 2004">{{cite journal | last = Risman | first = Barbara J. | author-link = Barbara Risman | title = Gender as a social structure: theory wrestling with activism | journal = [[Gender & Society]] | volume = 18 | issue = 4 | pages = 429–450 | publisher = [[Sage Publications|Sage]] | doi = 10.1177/0891243204265349 | jstor = 4149444 | date = August 2004 | url = https://doi.org/10.1177/0891243204265349 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Basow | first = Susan A. | title = Gender: stereotypes and roles | publisher = Brooks/Cole | location = Pacific Grove, California | year = 1992 | edition = 3rd | isbn = 9780534121204 }}</ref> Some parts of the masculinist movement have to some extent borrowed concepts from [[evolutionary psychology]]: this theory argues that adaptation during prehistory resulted in complementary but different roles for the different genders, and that this balance has been destabilized by feminism since the 1960s.<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/>
===Feminism=== Some masculinists have been described as explicitly antifeminist by feminist activists.<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/> According to Blais and Dupuis-Déri, "the contents of [masculinist] websites and the testimony of feminists that we questioned confirm that masculinists are generally critical of even moderate feminists and feminists at the head of official feminist organizations."<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/> Some masculinist activism has involved disruption of events organized by feminists and lawsuits against feminist academics, journalists, or activists.<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/> Furthermore, masculinist actions are sometimes extreme; father's rights activists have bombed family courts in Australia and have issued bomb threats in the UK, although it is ambiguous whether there was public and organized militant group involvement.<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/> They have also engaged in "tire-slashing, the mailing of excrement-filled packages, threats against politicians and their children."<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/> Spokesmen for these groups have also spoken out against public awareness campaigns to prevent sexual assault, arguing that they portray a negative image of men, and one masculinist group harassed administrators of dozens of battered women's shelters and women's centers.<ref name="Blais, Melissa 2012"/><ref>{{cite book | last1 = Martin | first1 = Janet M. | last2 = Borrelli | first2 = Maryanne | title = The other elites: Women, politics, and power in the Executive Branch | publisher = Lynne Rienner Publishers | location = Boulder, Colorado | year = 2001 | isbn = 9781555879716 }}</ref>
Philosopher Ferrell Christensen states that if masculism and feminism refer to the belief that men/women are systematically discriminated against, and that this discrimination should be eliminated, there is not necessarily a conflict between feminism and masculism, and some assert that they are both.<ref name="Honderich1995"/> However, many believe that one sex is more discriminated against, and thus use one label and reject the other.<ref name="Honderich1995"/>
==See also== {{Wiktionary|masculism}} {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Identity politics]] * [[Manosphere]] * [[Masculine psychology]] * [[Masculinity]] * [[Men's liberation]] * [[Men's movement]] * [[Men's rights movement]] * [[Men's studies]] {{div col end}}
;Men's organizations * [[Fathers 4 Justice]] * [[International Men's Day]] (19 November) ::[[Trinidad and Tobago]], [[Jamaica]], [[Australia]], [[India]], [[United States]], [[Singapore]], [[United Kingdom]], [[Malta]], [[South Africa]], [[Hungary]], [[Ireland]], [[Ghana]] and [[Canada]] * [[Save Indian Family]]
;Notable people associated with masculism * [[Warren Farrell]] * [[Robert Bly]]
;Books * ''[[Manliness (book)|Manliness]]'' (2006)
{{Portalbar|Masculinism|Human Rights|Men's rights|Discrimination}}
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Bibliography== ;Books * {{cite book | last = August | first = Eugene | title = The new men's studies: a selected and annotated interdisciplinary bibliography | publisher = Libraries Unlimited | location = Englewood, Colorado | edition = 2nd | year = 1994 | isbn = 9781563080845 }} * {{cite book | last = Baumeister | first = Roy | author-link = Roy Baumeister | title = Is there anything good about men?: How cultures flourish by exploiting men | publisher = Oxford University Press | location = Oxford New York | year = 2010 | isbn = 9780195374100 }} * {{cite book | last = Bax| first = Ernest Belfort | author-link = Ernest Belfort Bax | title = [[s:The Legal Subjection of Men|The legal subjection of men]] | publisher = New Age Press | location = London | year = 1908 | oclc = 33295675 }} ::''Antithesis of'': {{cite book | last = Mill | first = John Stuart | author-link = John Stuart Mill | title = [[The Subjection of Women|The subjection of women]] | publisher = D. Appleton & Co. | location = New York | year = 1869 | oclc = 15643538}} * {{cite book | last = Bax| first = Ernest Belfort | author-link = Ernest Belfort Bax | title = [[s:The Fraud of Feminism|The fraud of feminism]] | publisher = Grant Richards | location = London | year = 1913 | oclc = 33342327 }} * {{cite book | last = Benatar | first = David | title = The second sexism: discrimination against men and boys | publisher = Wiley-Blackwell | location = Malden, MA Oxford | year = 2012 | isbn = 9780470674512 }}
* {{cite book | last = Christen | first = Yves | title = Sex differences: modern biology and the unisex fallacy | publisher = Routledge | year = 2017 | isbn = 9781315129228 }} * {{cite book | last = Cose | first = Ellis | title = A man's world: how real is male privilege and how high is its price | publisher = Harper Collins Publishers | location = New York, New York | year = 1995 | isbn = 9780060172060 }} * {{cite book | last = Farrell | first = Warren | title = [[The Myth of Male Power|The myth of male power: why men are the disposable sex]] | publisher = [[Berkley Books]] | location = New York | year = 2001 | isbn = 9780425181447 }} * {{cite book | last = Fekete | first = John | title = Moral panic: biopolitics rising | publisher = Robert Davies Publishing | location = Montréal | year = 1994 | isbn = 9781895854091 }} * {{cite book | last = Gordon | first = John | title = The myth of the monstrous male, and other feminist fables | publisher = [[Playboy|Playboy Press]] | location = New York | year = 1982 | isbn = 9780872237582 }} * {{cite book | last = Hoff Sommers | first = Christina | author-link = Christina Hoff Sommers | title = [[Who Stole Feminism? How Women Have Betrayed Women|Who stole feminism?: how women have betrayed women]] | publisher = Touchstone/Simon & Schuster | location = New York | year = 1995 | isbn = 9780684801568 }} * {{cite book | last = Hoff Sommers | first = Christina | author-link = Christina Hoff Sommers | title = The war against boys: how misguided feminism is harming our young men | publisher = Simon & Schuster | location = New York | year = 2000 | isbn = 9780684849560 }} * {{cite book | last = James | first = Thomas B. | title = Domestic violence: the 12 things you aren't supposed to know | publisher = Aventine Press | location = Chula Vista, California | year = 2003 | isbn = 9781593301224 }} * {{cite book | last = Kammer | first = Jack | title = Good will toward men: women talk candidly about the balance of power between the sexes | publisher = St. Martin's Press | location = New York | year = 1994 | isbn = 9780312104719 }} * {{cite book | last = Kimbrell | first = Andrew | title = The masculine mystique: the politics of masculinity | publisher = Ballantine Books | location = New York | year = 1995 | isbn = 9780345386588 }} * {{cite book | last = Mansfield | first = Harvey | author-link = Harvey Mansfield | title = Manliness | publisher = Yale University Press | location = New Haven | year = 2006 | url = http://yalepress.yale.edu/yupbooks/book.asp?isbn=0300106645 | isbn = 9780300129939 }} * {{cite book | last1 = Moir | first1 = Anne | last2 = Moir | first2 = Bill | title = Why men don't iron: the fascinating and unalterable differences between men and women | publisher Inc. | location = New York | year = 1993 | isbn = 9780688110246 }} * {{cite book | last = Webb | first = Robert | author-link = Robert Webb | title = How not to be a boy | publisher = Canongate | location = Edinburgh | year = 2017 | isbn = 9781786890085 }} * {{cite book | last = Wilson | first = Robert | title = Email to the universe: and other alterations of consciousness | publisher = New Falcon Publications | location = Tempe, Ariz | year = 2005 | isbn = 9781561841943 }} * {{cite book | last = Young | first = Cathy | title = Ceasefire!: why women and men must join forces to achieve true equality | publisher = Free Press | location = New York, New York | year = 1999 | isbn = 9780684834429 }} * {{cite book | last = Zeff | first = Ted | title = The strong sensitive boy: help your son become a happy, confident man | publisher = Prana Publishing | location = San Ramon, California | year = 2010 | isbn = 9780966074529 }}

;Journal articles * {{Cite journal | last = Hill | first = Darryl B. | title = “Feminine” heterosexual men: subverting heteropatriarchal sexual scripts? | journal = [[The Journal of Men's Studies]] | volume = 14 | issue = 2 | pages = 161–172 | publisher = [[Men's Studies Press]] via [[Sage Publishing|Sage]] | doi = 10.3149/jms.1402.145 | date = March 2007 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.3149/jms.1402.145 | ref = harv | postscript = .}}

revision.comment: /* Extra-musical implications */
revision.text:
{{Redirects|Melodic figure||Melodic pattern}} [[File:Passamezzo and Romanesca.png|thumb|330px|[[Passamezzo]] and [[Romanesca]] melodic formulaApel, Willi (1997). ''The History of Keyboard Music to 1700'', p. 263. Trans. Tischler, Hans. {{ISBN|0-253-21141-7}}. on D {{audio|Passamezzo and Romanesca.mid|Play}}.]] '''Melody type''' or '''type-melody'''David Hiley. ''Western Plainchant. A Handbook''. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 1993, pp. 331–33. is a set of [[melody|melodic]] formulas, [[figure (music)|figures]], and [[melodic pattern|patterns]]. == Term and typical meanings == "Melody type" is a fundamental notion for understanding a nature of Western and non-Western musical [[Mode (music)|modes]], according to [[Harold Powers|Harold Powers']] seminal article "Mode" in the first edition of the ''[[New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians]]'' {{harv|Powers|1980|loc=12:376–77, 379, et passim}}. Melody types are used in the [[musical composition|composition]] of an enormous variety of [[music]], especially [[music of Asia|non-Western]] and [[early music|early Western music]]. Such music is generally composed by a process of [[centonization]], either freely (i.e. improvised) or in a fixed pattern. "Melody type" as used by the ethmnomusicologist [[Mark Slobin|Mark]] {{harvtxt|Slobin|1982|loc=186}}Slobin, Mark (1982). ''Tenement Songs: The Popular Music of the Jewish Immigrants''. Music in American Life. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. {{ISBN|0-252-00893-6}}. is defined as a "group of melodies that are related, in that they all contain similar modal procedures and characteristic [[rhythm]]ic and melodic contours or patterns".Koskoff, Ellen (2000). ''Music in Lubavitcher Life'' (Urbana: University of Illinois Press), p. 86. {{ISBN|978-0-252-02591-4}}. Most cultures which compose music in this way organize the patterns into distinct melody types. These are often compared to modern Western [[musical scale|scale]]s, but they in fact represent much more information than a sequence of permissible [[pitch (music)|pitches]], since they include how those pitches should function in the music, and indicate basic formulas which serve as a basis for [[improvisation]]. In non-improvised music, such as codified liturgical music, it is still usually clear how the melody developed from set patterns. {{quote|On one end of the continuum, the right, the melody type is a schema that is quite definite—a specific melody or a tune. When a musician improvises on this schema, he [or she] plays the melody with only slight variations. The basic outline is preserved and is clearly recognized by the listener. The best example ... on this end of the continuum is a folk song. A genuine folk song performance is a kind of improvisation. No one person sings it exactly as it came to him [or her]. One of the challenges of folk song research, of course, is to find all the variants of the tune and to try to trace the family relationships.
On the left side of the continuum is the melody type as a [[musical mode|mode]]. Here the melody type is similar to a [[Gregorian mode|church mode]]: a scalar configuration with a preferential order of tones.
...The closer we get to the pole where a melody type is a tune, the more definite and literal is the schema.|May (1983)May, Elizabeth (1983). ''Musics of Many Cultures: An Introduction, Part 1'', p. 274. {{ISBN|978-0-520-04778-5}}.}} {{quote|A melodic formula, ranging length from a short motif of a few notes to an entire melody, which is used as the basis for musical compositions. It differs from a mode, which simply sets forth a sequence of [[interval (music)|intervals]] (in Western music, half tones and whole tones), and from a scale (the notes of a mode in rising order of pitch), in that it is more specific: a melody type spells out actual sequences of tones, just as they are to appear in a piece, as well as particular beginnings and endings, [[ornament (music)|ornaments]], and other details. Melody types are found mostly in the music of ancient peoples—the Greeks, Hebrews, and others—and of Eastern peoples—the Arabs, Persians (Iranians), Indians, and others. For...example...[[raga]].|Ammer (2004)Ammer, Christine (2004). "Melody type", ''The Facts on File Dictionary of Music'', p. 238. {{ISBN|978-0-8160-5266-0}}.}} == Melodic formulae and melody types in monodic traditions around the world == * [[Nomos (music)|Nomos]] in [[Music of Ancient Greece|Ancient Greek music]] [[File:Formulae tonorum.jpg|thumb|400px|Ancient type-melodies for 8 church ('Gregorian') tones. Transcribed from the South-French tonary of the 10th century (Ms.: F-Pn lat. 1121, fol. 201v-205v). Pseudo-liturgical verses with initial numerals (''primum..., secundum..., tertia...'' etc.) helped singers to associate a current model with a 'real' chant (such as antiphon) of the same tone. These type-melodies were probably conceived as didactic, to adjust ear for typical melodic formulae, reciting tones, finals etc. They should not be confused with psalm tones, which represent an exact scheme for modulating psalms and canticles.David Hiley, ''Western Plainchant: A Handbook'' (Oxford and New York: Oxford University Press, 1993): pp. 58-69 and pp. 331-335; this handbook is itself a summary of specialized studies of intonation formulas by Michel Huglo, Terence Bailey, [[Bruno Stäblein]], and many others referred to at pp. 58 and 325 et passim. See also: Fiona McAlpine, ''Tonal Consciousness and the Medieval West'' (Bern: Peter Lang, 2008): p. 112.]] * Intonation formula ({{lang-lat|intonatio}}, [[euouae]], Noeane etc.) in [[Gregorian chant]] as used in [[psalm tone]]s and certain genres such as the [[Tract (liturgy)|Tract]]''Bailey T.'' The Intonation Formulas of Western Chant. Toronto, 1974. * [[Echos|Enechema]] ({{lang-grc|ἐνήχημα}}) in [[Byzantine chant]] * Popevka ({{lang-rus|попевка}}) in [[Znamennoe singing|Znamenny chant]] * [[Khaz (notation)|Khaz]] in [[Armenian chant]] * All Near and Middle East maqam-traditions ([[Arabic maqam|Arabic Maqam]], [[Makam|Turkish Makam]], [[Meqam|Kurdish Meqam]], [[Muqam|Uyghur Muqam]], [[Mugam|Azeri Mugam]], [[Shashmakom|Uzbek and Tadzhik Shashmakom]], [[Dastgah|Persian Dastgah]] etc.) * [[Raga]] in [[Music of India|Indian music]] * [[Pathet]] in [[Indonesian music]] * [[Choshi (music)|Chōshi]] in [[Japanese music]] ==Extra-musical implications== In most cases, these melody types are associated with extra-musical implications, particularly [[emotion]]s (see Indian [[rasa (art)|rasa]], for instance). They are also often associated with certain times. For example, most [[raga]]s are associated with a certain time of day, or a [[wayang]] performance in Java implies a certain succession of [[pathet]]s. Many of these traditions have a corresponding rhythmic framework. These include: * [[Usul (music)|Usul]] in Arabian and Turkish music * [[Tala (music)|Tala]] in Indian music * [[Bentuk]] in Javanese music ==See also== *[[Formula composition]] *[[Matrix (music)|Matrix]] *[[Modal frame]] ==Sources== {{reflist}} {{Melody}} {{Melody types}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Melody Type}} [[Category:Melody types| ]] [[Category:Musicology]]

'''[[Microarchitecture]] simulation''' is an important technique in [[computer architecture]] research and [[computer science]] education. It is a tool for modeling the design and behavior of a [[microprocessor]] and its components, such as the [[Arithmetic logic unit|ALU]], [[CPU cache|cache memory]], [[control unit]], and data path, among others. The simulation allows researchers to explore the design space as well as to evaluate the performance and efficiency of novel microarchitecture features. For example, several microarchitecture components, such as [[branch predictors]], [[re-order buffer]], and [[trace cache]], went through numerous simulation cycles before they become common components in contemporary microprocessors of today. In addition, the simulation also enables educators to teach computer organization and architecture courses with hand-on experiences.
For system-level simulation of computer hardware, please refer to the [[full system simulation]].
==Classification== Microarchitecture simulation can be classified into multiple categories according to input types and level of details. Specifically, the input can be a trace collected from an execution of program on a real microprocessor (so called trace-driven simulation) or a program itself (so called execution-driven simulation).
A trace-driven simulation<ref>Uhlig, R. A., & Mudge, T. N. (2004). Trace-Driven Memory Simulation: A Survey. ''ACM Computing Surveys'', 29(2), 128-170.</ref> reads a fixed sequence of trace records from a file as an input. These trace records usually represent memory references, branch outcomes, or specific machine instructions, among others. While a trace-driven simulation is known to be comparatively fast and its results are highly reproducible, it also requires a very large storage space. On the other hand, an execution-driven simulation<ref>Burger, D., & Austin, T. M. (1997). The Simplescalar Tool Set Version 2.0. ''Computer Architecture News'', 25(3), 13-25.</ref> reads a program and simulates the execution of machine instructions on the fly. A program file is typically several magnitudes smaller than a trace file. However, the execution-driven simulation is much slower than the trace-driven simulation because it has to process each instruction one-by-one and update all statuses of the microarchitecture components involved. Thus, the selection of input types for simulation is a trade-off between space and time. In particular, a very detailed trace for a highly accurate simulation requires a very large storage space, whereas a very accurate execution-driven simulation takes a very long time to execute all instructions in the program.
Apart from input types, the level of details can also be used to classify the simulation. In particular, a piece of software that simulates a microprocessor executing a program on a cycle-by-cycle basis is known as [[cycle-accurate simulator]], whereas [[instruction set simulator]] only models the execution of a program on a microprocessor through the eyes of an instruction scheduler along with a coarse timing of instruction execution. Most computer science classes in computer architecture with hand-on experiences adopt the instruction set simulators as tools for teaching, whereas the cycle-accurate simulators are deployed mostly for research projects due to both complexities and resource consumption.
==Usages== Microarchitecture simulators are deployed for a variety of purposes. It allows researchers to evaluate their ideas without the need to fabricate a real microprocessor chip, which is both expensive and time consuming. For instance, simulating a microprocessor with thousand of cores along with multiple levels of cache memory incurs very little cost when comparing with the fabrication of a prototyping chip. The researchers can also play with several configurations of the cache hierarchy using different cache models in the simulator instead of having to fabricate a new chip every time they want to test something different.
Another usage of the microarchitecture simulator is in education.<ref>Skadron, K. (1996). A Microprocessor Survey Course for Learning Advanced Computer Architecture. In Proceedings of the 2002 ACM SIGCSE Conference, 152-156.</ref> Given that a course in computer architecture teaches students many different microprocessor's features and its architectures, the microarchitecture simulator is ideal for modeling and experimenting with different features and architectures over the course of a semester. For example, students may start with a microarchitecture simulator that models a simple microprocessor design at the beginning of a semester. As the semester progresses, additional features, such as [[instruction pipelining]], [[register renaming]], [[reservation stations]], [[out-of-order execution]], and [[scoreboarding]], can be modeled and added to the simulator as they are introduced in the classroom. Microarchitecture simulator provides the flexibility of reconfiguration and testing with minimal costs.
==Examples== * Shade<ref>Cmelik, R. F., & Keppel, D. (1994). Shade: A Fast Instruction-Set Simulator for Execution Profiling. ''ACM SIGMETRICS Performance Evaluation Review'', 22(1), 128-137.</ref> (trace-driven, instruction set simulator) * SimpleScalar<ref>Austin, T., Larson, E., & Ernst, D. (2002). SimpleScalar: An Infrastructure for Computer System Modeling. ''IEEE Computer Magazine'', 35(2), 59-67.</ref> (execution-driven, cycle-accurate simulator) * [[SPIM]]<ref>Patterson, D. A., & Hennessy, J. L. (2011). ''Computer Organization and Design: The Hardware/Software Interface'', Morgan Kaufmann.</ref> (execution-driven, instruction set simulator) * SMTSIM<ref>Tullsen, D. M. (1996). Simulation and Modeling of a Simultaneous Multithreading Processor. In Proceedings of the 22nd Annual Computer Measurement Group Conference.</ref> (execution-driven, cycle-accurate simulator)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.simplescalar.com The Official SimpleScalar Website] * [http://spimsimulator.sourceforge.net The Official SPIM Website] * [http://cseweb.ucsd.edu/~tullsen/smtsim.html The SMTSIM Multithreading Simulator]
[[Category:Computer architecture]] [[Category:Simulation]] [[Category:Simulation software]]

revision.text:
'''Mono-ha''' (もの派) is the name given to a group of 20th-century Japanese artists. The Mono-ha artists explored the encounter between natural and industrial materials, such as stone, steel plates, glass, light bulbs, cotton, sponge, paper, wood, wire, rope, leather, oil, and water, arranging them in mostly unaltered, ephemeral states. The works focus as much on the interdependency of these various elements and the surrounding space as on the materials themselves.
==Origin of the Term “Mono-ha” and its Members==
“Mono-ha” is usually translated in a literal manner, as “School of Things.” The Mono-ha artists regularly assert that “Mono-ha” was a term disparagingly coined by critics (specifically Teruo Fujieda and Toshiaki Minemura in ''Bijutsu Techo'' magazine in 1973) well after they had begun to exhibit their work, and they did not begin as an organized collective. Many of the Mono-ha artists were first exhibited at Tamura and Maki Galleries in Tokyo owned by Nobuo[[(Shinro) Yamagiishi]] who was also an art writer and whose archives are in the collection of [[The National Art Center Tokyo]].
Toshiaki Minemura explains in his 1986 essay “What Was Mono-ha?,” that in terms of their academic background and intellectual exchange, the Mono-ha artists are divided into three groups:<ref>Minemura, Toshiaki. [https://www.kamakura.gallery/mono-ha/minemura-en.html "What was MONO-HA?"], ''MONO-HA'', Kamakura Gallery, 1986, p.6</ref>
# '''"The [[Lee Ufan|Lee]] + [[Tama Art University|Tamabi]] Connection.”''' This comprises [[Nobuo Sekine]], [[Kishio Suga]], Shingo Honda, Katsuhiko Narita and Katsurō Yoshida in the painting department, and [[Susumu Koshimizu]] in the sculpture department at [[Tama Art University]] (aka Tamabi) as well as [[Jiro Takamatsu]] and [[Lee Ufan]], a Korean artist who is a close friend of Sekine. # '''“The [[Tokyo University of the Arts|Geidai Connection]],”''' a group of artists around [[Kōji Enokura]] and Noboru Takayama, who were both graduates of the [[Tokyo University of the Arts]] (aka Geidai), and Hiroshi Fujii and Makoto Habu, who were involved in Mono-ha later on. # '''“The [[Nihon University|Nichidai]] Connection,”''' students from the [[Nihon University]] (aka Nichidai) Fine Arts Department—whose central figure was Noriyuki Haraguchi—also known as the “Yokosuka Group,” due to Haraguchi’s upbringing in Yokosuka and his critique of the local US military presence through his work.<ref>''Kishio Suga''. Los Angeles: Blum & Poe, 2012, p.8</ref>
==Socio-Political Context==
Mono-ha emerged in response to a number of social, cultural and political precedents set in the 1960s. With the exception of Lee Ufan, who was a decade older, most of the Mono-ha artists were just beginning their careers when the violent student protests of 1968–69 occurred.
At the same time, there was much protest against the second extension of the US-Japan Security Treaty (known in abbreviated Japanese as ''[[Anpo]]'') in 1970, binding Japan into providing logistical support for the US war in Vietnam. Coupled with demands for the reversion of [[Okinawa]] by 1972 and the removal of nuclear weapons based there, the climate of protest during this period was symptomatic of a growing distrust of the United States’ intentions towards Asia and its dominant position in the bilateral relationship with Japan. The activism of the “''Anpo'' generation” gave rise to a highly intellectual counterculture that was both critical of US “[[imperialism]]” and acutely self-aware of its Japanese identity.<ref>Munroe, Alexandra. ''Japanese Art After 1945: Scream Against the Sky''. Harry N. Abrams Inc, 1994. p.215</ref>
The Mono-ha artists typically deny involvement with student activist movements at the time, though it is thought that the tense political climate influenced their work, allowing them to grapple with and make sense of their unease and disillusionment with postwar modernity in their different ways.
==Recent Attention in the United States==
In 2012, [[Blum & Poe]] gallery introduced the Mono-ha art into the US with the survey exhibition “Requiem for the Sun: The Art of Mono-ha,” curated by Mika Yoshitake. The gallery has also held solo exhibitions of [[Lee Ufan]], [[Kishio Suga]], [[Susumu Koshimizu]], [[Koji Enokura]], and [[Nobuo Sekine]].
==Phase-Mother Earth== {{Infobox artwork | image_file = | painting_alignment = | image_size = | title = Phase-Mother Earth | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = Nobuo Sekine | year = 1968, 2008 and 2012 | type = [[earth art]] | height_metric = 2.7 | width_metric = 2.2 | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = 2.2 | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = m| imperial_unit = in<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default in. Not including it will default it to in.--> | italic title = no | city = [[Kobe]], [[Suma Rikyu Park]] | museum = | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = }}
[[Nobuo Sekine]]'s '''Phase-Mother Earth''' is considered to be the initial work of the Mono-ha movement.<ref>{{cite news |title=Series: 1000 artworks to see before you die |first= |last= |url= https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2008/oct/30/sargent-saxon-serrano?INTCMP=SRCH|newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 October 2008 |accessdate=2 August 2011}}</ref> Originally created in Suma Rikyu Park in [[Kobe]], and without official permission. The work was re-created in 2008<ref>{{cite journal |last1= Rawlings|first1=Ashley|year= 2008|title=Nobuo Sekine's "Phase-Mother Earth" Under Reconstruction |journal=Art Space Tokyo |volume= |issue= October 28|pages= |publisher= |doi= |url= http://artspacetokyo.com/blog/archives/nobuo_sekines_phase_mother_earth_under_reconstruction/ |accessdate= 31 July 2011}}</ref> and 2012. It was a large cylindrical tower made of packed earth, which was removed from a cylindrical hole with the same shape.
==Members== *[[Jiro Takamatsu]] *[[Nobuo Sekine]] *[[Lee Ufan]] *[[Kishio Suga]] *[[Koji Enokura]] *[[Susumu Koshimizu]] *[[Noboru Takayama]] *[[Katsuhiko Narita]] *[[Noriyuki Haraguchi]] *[[Katsuro Yoshida]] *[[Kenji Inumaki]] *[[Shingo Honda]]
==Bibliography==
*''Japon des avant gardes: 1910–1970''. Paris: Centre Georges Pompidou, 1986. *Chong, Doryun. ''Tokyo 1955–1970: A New Avant-Garde''. New York: Museum of Modern Art, 2012. *Koplos, Janet. ''Contemporary Japanese Sculpture''. New York: Abbeville Press, 1991. *Munroe, Alexandra. ''Japanese Art After 1945: Scream Against the Sky''. New York: Harry N. Abrams Inc, 1994. *Yoshitake, Mika. ''Requiem for the Sun: The Art of Mono-ha''. Los Angeles: Blum & Poe, 2012. *''Kishio Suga''. Los Angeles: Blum & Poe, 2012
==References== {{reflist}}
